Tensor objects¶

Bottle provides an N-dimensional array type, the Tensor, which describes a collection of “items” of the same type. The items can be indexed using for example N integers.

All Tensors are homogenous: every item takes up the same size block of memory, and all blocks are interpreted in exactly the same way. How each item in the array is to be interpreted is specified by a separate data-type object, one of which is associated with every tensor.

An item extracted from an array, e.g., by indexing, is represented by a Crystal object whose type is one of the scalar types used in Bottle. The array scalars allow easy manipulation of also more complicated arrangements of data.

  • The N-dimensional tensor

    • Indexing arrays
    • Internal memory layout of an Tensor
    • Array attributes
    • Array methods
    • Arithmetic, matrix multiplication, and comparison operations
    • Special methods
